texts.shortText:
Nemerteans are soft-bodied, flattened, unsegmented worms that are best known for their ability to vary enormously in length. When observed alive they can become extremely elongated, but when collected or disturbed they contract and adopt a much shorter and thicker shape. The South African fauna is poorly studied and many species certainly remain undescribed.

This species is best identified by its blue-grey body colour and the transverse white band just behind the head; the ‘lips’ around the mouth are also white.
About 50 mm when contracted, but can extend to 20 cm or more when alive.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: About Lambert’s Bay on west coast to Eastern Cape.

Found under rocks and insinuated among sedentary animals on rocky shores. Moves around by gliding along on a bed of cilia, or by stretching out and extending the body through small gaps. Can be very hard to untangle and examine and often breaks if handled. There are no gills or other respiratory organs and gas exchange takes place across the extensive body surface.

All nemertines are predatory and shoot out an elongate proboscis from a special cavity just above the mouth to capture prey, which consists of other small invertebrates, such as polychaetes, bivalves and crustaceans.

Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are shed into the water. Some species guard the eggs, but reproductive behaviour is not known for South African species. Can also regenerate from broken pieces. In some species body fragmentation is routine and even broken sections from near the tail can re-grow full bodies.

Best recognized by colour pattern. A second member of the genus Lineus lacticapitatus occurs in much the same region and has similar habits, but is purple-brown to bright red and had an entirely white head.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 62)

Wheeler, JFG (1940). Some nemerteans from South Africa and a note on Lineus corrugatus M'Intosh. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 41(276), 20-49.
